Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Enhancement: Investigating Chloroflexi mats at a Japanese Hot Spring as a Model for Anoxygenic Stromatolites
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although we usually think of life on Earth in terms of complex multicellular organisms like plants and animals, these have evolved only relatively recently, in the last 600 million years of Earth?s 4.5 billion year history. Earlier, all life on Earth was microbial, made up of organisms like bacteria and algae. Although these organisms look simple they are responsible for some of the most important inventions in biology, including oxygenic photosynthesis?the ability to take water, sunlight, and CO2 and to produce sugar and oxygen. While this process occurs in plants today it was first invented by a group of organisms called Cyanobacteria. The production of oxygen by photosynthetic Cyanobacteria completely changed how the Earth?s surface worked, by producing the ozone layer, providing oxygen for aerobic respiration, and allowing oxygen to play a role in chemical weathering of rocks. This change occurred about 2.3 billion years ago. It isn?t well understood, however, whether Cyanobacteria evolved and invented oxygenic photosynthesis right around this time or much earlier in Earth history. Because individual bacteria don't leave good fossils, one of the best ways of looking for when they evolved is by observing preserved microbial mats in ancient rocks. This award supports doctoral dissertation research by U.S. graduate student Lewis Ward to study microbial mats forming in hot springs in Japan, where similar microbial mats are being formed today by Cyanobacteria and Chloroflexi, a group of bacteria which performs photosynthesis but without releasing oxygen. By studying these two types of mats and seeing how they differ, it is possible to determine which features of microbial mats are preserved in the rock record and can be used to distinguish which group of organisms produced them. By comparing these features to preserved microbial mats throughout the rock record, we can better understand the history of Cyanobacteria, photosynthesis, and oxygen and, by extension, the origins of life on Earth. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Professor Shawn McGlynn, an expert on microbial communities in the environment, at Tokyo Metropolitan University in Japan.

Stromatolites are layered, accretionary sedimentary structures often formed by the interaction of microbes with sediments. With a record dating back 3. 5 billion years, they are among the  earliest evidence for life on Earth. While similar structures may form in the absence of biology, extensive investigation of modern analogs provides robust criteria for identifying the biogenicity  of many ancient stromatolites. Known modern stromatolite analogs are formed by oxygenic Cyanobacteria, which leads to interpretation of ancient stromatolites as indicators of the presence of Cyanobacteria performing oxygenic photosynthesis. However, independent geological proxies suggest that Cyanobacteria and oxygen appear relatively late, closer to the rise of oxygen ca. 2. 35 Ga. Because Cyanobacteria evolved from anoxygenic ancestors, it is conceivable that early stromatolites were formed by anoxygenic phototrophs, but we have a poor understanding of whether and how this would  occur. In order to resolve this conundrum we propose to develop and study a model stromatolite-forming system composed of Chloroflexi--a phylum of facultatively aerobic filamentous bacteria capable of anoxygenic photoheterotrophy. To catalyze this work, this award supports a collaboration with researchers at Tokyo Metropolitan University who are among the foremost experts in the world at the isolation, cultivation, and physiological study of Chloroflexi. This project will be enhanced by access to natural Chloroflexi mats at a hot spring at the Nakabusa Onsen in Japan. This unique opportunity will allow effective development of a model system for anoxygenic stromatolites using Chloroflexi in both pure culture and using natural hot spring mats. This system will directly test whether or not stromatolites can form in the absence of photosynthesis (by growing them as aerobic heterotrophs), and if organisms performing anoxygenic phototrophy can form stromatolites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to characterize the microbial community at Nakabusa Onsen, a unique hot spring ecosystem in Japan, where microbial mats develop morphologies analogous to some ancient stromatolites. Stromatolites are among the earliest evidence for life on Earth, but the organisms and processes leading to their formation are poorly understood due to the limited number of well-characterized modern analogs. The characterization of stromatolite analogs in Japanese hot springs therefore has the potential to greatly improve our interpretation of the early rock record of life. The stromatolite-analog microbial mats at Nakabusa Onsen are unique in that they are primarily built by Chloroflexi, a phylum of bacteria which includes members capable of anoxygenic photosynthesis, a way of making a living by conserving energy from light but without producing oxygen as a byproduct. This is thought to have been an ancient metabolism, responsible for supporting Earth’s early biosphere. 

In order to characterize the microbial community at Nakabusa Onsen and other Japanese hot springs, graduate student Lewis Ward traveled to Japan in summer of 2016 to measure the geochemistry of the springs and to collect samples of microbial mats for metagenomic sequencing and microscopic analysis. In addition to Nakabusa Onsen, two other hot springs were sampled—Oku-Okuhachikurou Onsen and Jinata Onsen. These hot springs also support novel microbial communities and are analogous to some environments on the ancient Earth.  Analysis of samples collected from these hot springs is still ongoing, but much valuable data has been collected so far including the geochemical makeup of hot spring water and characterization of the microbial communities form sites from all three hot springs as assessed by 16S amplicon and shotgun metagenomic sequencing. These sequencing efforts in particular have been valuable for revealing both the taxonomic and metabolic diversity of these hot spring ecosystems, and have revealed significant novel diversity, particularly among the Chloroflexi, including new lineages of phototrophs and nonphototrophs.

While additional results from microscopy and other forms of analysis will lead to further manuscripts, results from metagenomic sequencing and overall characterization of the hot spring systems has already produced one submitted manuscript and multiple manuscripts in preparation. These include overview descriptions of the hot spring localities and broad characterization of the microbial community based on 16S amplicon sequencing, as well as improved understanding of the diversity and evolution of the Chloroflexi phylum based on genomes recovered from metagenomic sequencing.  Manuscripts describing initial characterization of the hot springs and associated microbial communities will serve as an important resource for future work investigating these systems and applying them to interpretations of the ancient rock record. One such manuscript has been submitted to Geobiology and is currently in revision, while similar manuscripts for the other hot springs are in preparation. A manuscript describing diverse novel Chloroflexi genomes recovered from metagenomic sequencing data from Nakabusa Onsen and Jinata Onsen, and insights from these strains into the evolution of anoxygenic photosynthesis in this phylum, is currently in preparation. 

This project has significantly contributed to the graduated education of PhD candidate Lewis Ward. Ward has traveled to Japan to perform fieldwork and analysis, continuing a collaboration with Prof. Shawn McGlynn at the Earth-Life Science Institute at the Tokyo Institute of Technology. Ward has analyzed geochemical and metagenomic data and prepared the manuscripts resulting from these data, and has included versions of these manuscripts as chapters and appendices into his PhD thesis.

  • Ward, LM, P Shih, J Hemp, SE McGlynn, and WW Fischer. A Complex History of Phototrophy Revealed by Novel Chloroflexi Lineages. In preparation.
  • Ward, LM, WW Fischer, K Matsuura, and SE McGlynn. Cone-forming microbial mats of Nakabusa Onsen, Japan as analogs of Precambrian stromatolites. In prep.
  • Ward, LM, A Idei, WW Fischer, and SE McGlynn. Microbial diversity and productivity of Jinata Onsen, an iron-rich intertidal hot spring in Japan. In prep.
  • Ward, L. M. 2017. Microbial Evolution and the Rise of Oxygen: The Roles of Contingency and Context in Shaping the Biosphere through Time (Doctoral dissertation, California Institute of Technology).
